reviewText: A Aggressive College-Basketball Couch (Kevin Bacon) tries to Recuit a new player from the Kenyan Tribe.Directed by Paul Micheal Glasser (The Running Man, The Cutting Edge) has made a familiar but Often Goofy Comedy. Some of the Basketball Scenes are Extremely Funny. Filmed in South Arfica and Kenya. Grade:B.
Title: The Air Up There VHS

reviewText: Except for the presence of Kevin Bacon, whom I like a lot, this would have been a real loser.  There were so many things wrong.  Directed by Paul Glaser with no surprises, no depth of character, a too heavy-handed Hollywood scenario.  You knew what was coming a mile away.  There was good cinematography and music, and Kevin Bacon is always appealing, but that's the best I can say.  Oh, and the nun.  She was pretty good too.  The lead black man was also engaging; the problem was really the script.  Too pat, and too many unbelievable things that screamed "Hollywood".  Like when the village burned down.  They were ready to just up and leave where they'd lived for generations.  As if it takes generations to rebuild their houses.  And there were no signs of the burned buildings during the basketball game.  And Bacon was supposed to climb this incredible mountain, get cut in the groin, then play basketball, all on a rotten knee.  Please.
Title: The Air Up There VHS

reviewText: The Air Up There (1994) While there are absolutely no surprises in this comedy from Disney, at least it's pleasant and fairly entertaining. Kevin Bacon (Apollo 13) plays a hotshot assistant coach who travels to Africa to recruit a Winabi tribesman for his team. Once there he runs into all of the expected problems and culture shocks. I recommend this one to basketball nuts and the rainy Saturday afternoon crowd.
summary: Not a slam dunk, but not an airball either...
Title: The Air Up There VHS

reviewText: Hello out there & welcome to this, this is where I go back & review movies that either came out 20 years ago or 10 years ago. This is 20 years ago The Air Up There. When I started this series a couple of years ago I couldn't wait to cover the year 1994 cause that is 1 of the best years ever for movies. Now The Air Up There was made for $16 million & made $21 million in The US so it was a decent sized hit. It was directed by Paul Michael Glaser who directed The Running Man & Kazaam I like The Running Man I haven't seen Kazaam since I was 11. Glaser has done mostly TV work. The movie stars Kevin Bacon as Jimmy Dolan, Charles Ditinga Maina as Seleh & Mabutho Sithole as Nyaga. The story is about this Assistant Coach named Jimmy Dolan & he meets this young man named Buddy Wilson who is brought over to play for The ST Joseph Bulls. He really only cares about money. He challenges Jimmy to a little 1 on 1 where Jimmy wins that sets Buddy off & he leaves The Head Coach is mad at him he let Jimmy go & Jimmy wants to become The Head Coach especially after The Head Coach announces his retirement he sees a video of this Kenyan man named Seleh who is great at Basketball. Jimmy wants a team player so he wants to bring Seleh to America & get a team player cause Buddy wasn't in it for the team. He goes off to Kenya he meets this man named Nyaga who comes more into play later on he makes his way to a village where he meets Seleh & he wants to bring him over here but there's a problem Seleh's Father is like some kind of Tribe Leader & Seleh is the next in line. Now you have this 1 character I won't really talk about named Sister Susan played by Yolanda Vazquez I have never heard of her before & I guess it shows. There are good bits of humor in this movie like when Kevin Bacon drinks some kind of milk looking stuff & it gives him an upset stomach or when he fails to understand their language. You also find out about Nyaga who is the leader of this enemy tribe he has taken a lot of their land & cattle & Seleh's Brother turned on them & joined Nyaga. You have these 2 Tribe members that are going to get married 1 of Nyaga's Men show up & burn the villagers huts down. You have The Village Leader challenge The Enemy Tribe to a game of Basketball if they win they get their land back & Seleh will go with Jimmy to The US but if The Enemy Tribe wins they take all the remaining land. Jimmy has 8 days to to get the villagers ready to play The Enemy Tribe. 1 of the villagers gets hurt Seleh asks Jimmy to take his place but explains that he blew out his knee back in 1981 when he won The State Championship. Seleh tells him he has to become 1 of them & he believes in him. he goes through this process to become part of The Tribe the part where he climbs the mountain is imo the best part of the movie. Anyway we get to The B Ball game & you know it starts off bad for Jimmy's Team & Jimmy's knee is injured you have this woman from The Tribe get in the game she gets thrown out when she starts roughhousing. Jimmy gets back in the game against everyone's wishes The Head Coach from ST Joseph shows up & Seleh says even if we lose he's coming back with them Jimmy tells him to do whatever he wants cause he only cares about getting The Tribes land back. Things start to turn around for them so Nyaga has 1 of his men take out Jimmy knee then you have Nyaga's driver who is also Seleh's Brother turn against the enemey tribe & join back with his tribe. Basically he helps them get close to defeating them 1 point away & Nyaga calls time Jimmy works up a plan for the team to distract the other players & have it between Seleh & the big guy from Nyaga's Team & Nyaga use his Trademark Move "The Jimmy Dolan Shake & Bake." The plan works Jimmy's Team wins & the movie ends with Jimmy becoming The Head Coach & Seleh joining The ST Joseph Bulls. Now is this a great movie no but I thought it was pretty good. Paul Michael Glaser did a pretty good job directing. Kevin Bacon was good. Charles Gitonga Maina was decent. Mabutho Sithole did a decent job. I thought this movie was petty good as I said. The next review in this series will be 2004 in film The Butterfly Effect.
summary: 20 years ago The Air Up There 7/10
Title: The Air Up There VHS

reviewText: I'm a pretty well educated film goer--took film courses in college, read much, understand the vocabulary and history of film. AND I have a secret, forbidden list--a list of films I really love but critics didn't. Such gems as Gung Ho! (with Michael Keaton) and The Golden Child (Eddie Murphy) grace this list. Out with snobbery, in with fun I say!The Air Up There is definitely on my list. I hate basketball--I'm bored by sports in general. But I love this movie. It makes me feel good. Kevin Bacon is at his brash and cocky best as an assistant coach for a Catholic college team which apparently is expected to win big. When his personal pride costs him the loss of a promising prospect, he journeys to Africa to recruit a VERY tall fellow he saw in a home movie from a priest doing Good Works out there. When the basketball prospect turns out to be a prince and some tribal rivalry and mining interests complicate matters, the brash assistant coach has to find out what really matters.Cliched? Sure. Predictable. I hope to tell you. But I love it anyway. The acting is amiable, the characters fun, the setting just exotic enough, the writing sure-handed, the story uplifting, and I got excited watching the basketball sequences even though I hate the game.So what can I tell you? We talk now about not letting terrorists run our lives. I say don't let critics run your life either. I watch this movie at least twice a year and feel a whole lot happier when it's over. Try it.
summary: I Hate Basketball And Love The Movie
Title: The Air Up There VHS

reviewText: i searched for this movie everywhere finally found it on dvd sadly it was region2..luckily i had (note the word HAD) a region free dvd player in my room..i was so excited waiting for this movie to come 2 days before it arrived my 4 year decided to watch a movie in daddies room my dvd player is on a shelf above my bed long story short she fell off my bed ripping off the dvd tray..now another long wait as i wait for the new dvd player to arrive
